passages.text: WEN, SN, WSM, ANURBN, FIVE, SJM
Great note out from Rahul on WEN today walking through the path ahead and focusing on key KPIs at a critical juncture.
Recaps from yesterday's earnings are below from Research.
Intra- day volatility continues, with yday providing a few more examples:

- ANF (-1% yday) with a \(+15\%\) morning recovery from after opening down -10%, rallying to briefly green during the call, and then fading into the close (-10% total intra-day move).- WSM (-3% yday) with a -7% fade from after opening \(+3 - 4\%\) and then immediately dropping, recovering a bit midday, and fading into the close (-6% total intra-day move).- KSS (+24% yday) with a -10% fade after opening \(+29\%\) before bottoming out and rallying into the close (-4% intra-day move).- SJM (-4% yday) with a \(+6\%\) morning rally after opening -9%, peaking out midday and generally holding steady throughout the afternoon (-5% intra-day move).

- WEN: A (Perceived) Value Trap That Needn't Be - Potential Path Forward- SN: CEO Departure is a ST Overhang, Yet Interim CFO Well Positioned To Carry Smooth Transition- WSM: Managing Well + Guidance Appears Conservative, Albeit with Top-Line Questions; Key Mgmt Takes- ANF: Mgmt Follow-Up Takes & Model Implications; 2H Show-Me Setup- URBn: 2Q Beating 7UO Global Inflection; Mgmt Follow-Up Takes- FIVE: 2Q Beating 2H Upside Drivers In Place; Mgmt Takes & Model Implications- SJM: Thoughts on 2H Weighted Guidance (Some Timing Related and Some Incremental)
(1) WEN: A (perceived) value trap that needn't be - potential path forward here
Following the last few months of tumultuous headline performance, Wendy's U.S. business is at a critical juncture with several potential changes to the company's strategy being an opportunity.

The main goal of this piece is to dive into the company's capital allocation strategy and revisit the capital structure to improve the invest- ability of the equity story. New S14 Dec- 26 target price based on \(6.25\%\) F28 FCF yield (150bps discount to MCD/YUM/ QSR/DPZ) and 200bps to 10y TSY.

- Capital allocation going forward – specifically focusing on development, remodels, and return to shareholders - Shifting \(300m+\) development capex in F26-28 towards US system Remodels to improve medium-long term health of the franchise system. Argument for Wendy's BS support (like RBI) for faster (3y) capital light (\$200k) remodels.- Capital structure – right net leverage for the current business - maintain sub 4.5x leverage long term by opportunistically unlocking the real estate portfolio value by sale leasebacks and repaying debt.- Easy-to-address product and marketing opportunities. Clear value messaging (+leveraging digital channels) by consolidating biggie bags price points to market effectively, and rolling out simple to execute/minimally disruptive LTOs as stores refocus on tightening operations.

SharkNinja (SN, OW- rated) announced in a 6- K filing this morning that CFO Patraic Reagan resigned as CFO, effective September 5, 2025. The company added that "Mr. Reagan's resignation is not the result of any dispute or disagreement with the Company or its Board of Directors, including any matters relating to the Company's operations, policies, accounting practices, or financial reporting." The board is appointing Adam Quigley to serve as interim CFO, effective immediately upon Mr. Reagan's departure. Our take: while Patraic leaving unexpectedly after a short tenure (joined late April 2024) reads negative to us given the strong momentum, our understanding is that he is departing for another opportunity outside of small appliance industry, and we think the transition will be smooth. Mr. Reagan was the company's first permanent CFO since listing in the U.S. (had relied on interim CFO from listing in mid- 2023) and, as such, we think the company opted for a higher- profile external hire for the role perhaps at the expense of the right cultural fit for SN's faced paced/disruptive organization.

Even with the short \(\sim 15\) month tenure, Patraic was able to elevate the Finance functions, including bringing in new talent like James Lamb to be Treasurer and IR, and Mr. Quigley has been well involved in the supply chain transformation, tariff mitigation and international expansion in his \(\sim 10\) years with the company, which we believe will serve him well in the interim role. Additionally, while the company did not add language to the filing related to guidance, in our 1x1 conversation this morning IR confirmed there was no change to the outlook provided with 2Q25 results (link to model update note).

Short Term Volatility Possible Given Unexpected Departure, but Fundamentally a Smooth Transition. Adam has extensive experience at SN including the move to U.S. listing and all recent pivots in manufacturing, tariff mitigation, and international expansion. Mr. Quigley joined the Company in 2015 and has served as SVP Finance – Global Business Planning since September 2024. He previously served as SVP Finance – Global FP&A, Strategic Finance from June 2022 to September 2024 and as VP Finance – FP&A from December 2019 to June 2022.
(3) WSM: Managing Well + Guidance Appears Conservative, Albeit with Top-Line Questions; Key Mgmt Takes here

Strong print, although top line raises some questions; long- term rates in focus. Overall, WSM posted stronger- than- expected sales growth and profits (Figure 1), with the company showing its ongoing ability to flex costs in both directions relative to gross profit dollar performance (2Q featured a strong gross margin beat, partly offset by higher- than- forecast SG&A, mostly on incentive comp). While the market may have expected \(\sim 5\%\) comps, WSM raised sales guidance for the year, but kept the operating margin given its effective tariff rate doubled (14% to 28%) since reporting 1Q (though we view the margin guide conservatively, a point that seemed "transparent" on the call). That said, SSS accelerated only 30 bps to 3.7%, while CPI data indicated a 270- bp acceleration in pricing indicating WSM either: (1) held back on material pricing (unlikely given prior commentary, in our view); (2) had 1Q demand pull- forward ahead of tariffs (mgmt said no); or (3) experienced some trade- down (or lack of trade- up) as we've heard from other retailers that this trend accelerated in 1H25 (Overweight- rated W, a mass player, saw comps accelerate \(>300\) bps QOQ). Some QTD acceleration appears likely, however, given the midpoint of the updated guide

implies \(\sim 3.5\%\) SSS in 2H (the average of the past three quarters) and more inflation is coming, too, with the company expecting 4Q inflation \(>3Q > 2Q\) . Net- net, we expect the stock to see some relief from here given absolute sales strength, the potential for persistent margin- driven earnings upswing and Fed hope. That said, as we noted for HD/LOW, we believe the next significant move in the stock is more likely rate- driven (as we watch somewhat stubborn 30- year mortgage rates, with JPM economists expecting the Fed's impact to be focused at the short end of the curve).

Matt Boss remains Overweight w/ our Dec '26 Price Target of \(\) 145\((vs.\) \ \(151\) prior) based on \(\sim 6.5x\) our FY27E EBITDA supported by our linear regression analysis, with ANF's forward operating margins/sales growth profile \(\sim 800\) bps above the prepandemic fundamental profile. We model FY25 EPS of \(\) 10.06\((vs. Street\) \ \(10.11\) ) and FY26 EPS of \(\) 10.10\(vs. Street\) \ \(10.50\) ).

Key Takes: (1) Q2 revenues exceed consensus led by Hollister w/ improved July exit rate at A&F, (2) Q3 revenue outlook set above consensus w/ easing 2H AUR YoY compares at A&F brand, (3) FY25 margin outlook range raised towards upper half.
Matt Boss (OW) raises his PT to \(\) 89\(based on 13x FY27 EPS of 6.75. For FY25 and FY26 EPS he models 5.25 and 5.93, respectively.

Key call outs: (1) Core UO comp acceleration w/ exit rate and BTS momentum, (2) Anthro / FP momentum continues w/ broad- based demand, (3) Q2 GPM beat w/ FY25 raised to the high- end, and (4) 2H25 SG&A expenses guided in- line w/ sales growth.

Matt Remains Neutral / \(\) 154\(PT. We model FY25 EPS of\) \ \(4.97\) (vs. Street \(\) 4.71\() and FY26 EPS of\) \ \(5.15\) (vs. Street \(\) 5.24\(). Remain Neutral with\) \ \(154\) Dec '26 price target unchanged based on \(\sim 27x\) our FY27E EPS of \(\) 5.66\(= FIVE's trailing 5- year multiple), with aforementioned 4Q25 upside opportunity and subsequent fixed cost and tariff flow- through, we see FY27 EPS power of \(\sim\) 6.30 (vs. Street \(\) 5.92\(pointing to\) \ \(170\) equity value.

SJM shares were \(- 4\%\) on the day (S5PACK flat) following the company's first EPS miss in 6 years and an annual guidance reiteration, despite guiding for 2Q EPS to come in well below prior estimates (initial take). We agree that the print is disappointing, and despite the guidance reiteration, we think it is prudent to assume a bit weaker EPS for FY26 than our prior estimate. Nonetheless, we remain Overweight the shares. Progressively better earnings over the coming year still seem likely to us (albeit from a lower starting point in 2Q26). Over time, we expect more topline growth from SJM than from other similarly valued food peers, driven mainly by Uncrustables but also Pet (eventually). Finally, the company's continued debt paydown (FCF guidance was raised by \(\) 100\mathrm{MM}\(today) could also be a source of share price improvement over time.

Tweaking estimates and target price lower. The year is more 2H- weighted than we previously assumed (in part due to the timing of hedges) and relies on lower coffee elasticity holding and a partial earnings recovery for Sweet Baked Snacks (especially in 4Q). We think these assumptions are reasonable but not without incremental risk. FY26E goes to \(\) 9.02\(from\) \ \(9.19\) and FY27E to \(\) 9.82\(from\) \ \(9.94\) . Our December 2026 price target goes to \(\) 126\(from\) \ \(129\) , with the lowered earnings outlook partially offset by slightly higher expected free cash flow (which benefits net debt and interest expense).

Thoughts on the more 2H- weighted outlook. The incremental earnings pressure in 2Q is mainly related to the timing of hedges, which pulls forward coffee inflation into the quarter. This also means that coffee inflation (ex- tariffs) should be a bit lower than
North America Specialist Sales JPM | US CONSUMER: WEN, SN, WSM, ANF, URBIN, FIVE, SJM 28 August 2025

SJM previously expected in 2H26. The other 2H drivers in coffee would be incremental pricing (to combat the higher tariffs, which start to flow through in 3Q26) and lower elasticity on the first round of pricing. Outside of Coffee, Pet sales growth should benefit from lapping a work stoppage in 3Q and retailer inventory cuts in 4Q. Sweet Baked Snacks profit is expected to get sequentially better throughout FY26 as SJM's cost savings actions take hold, with the biggest step up coming in 4Q, when cost savings take hold. Finally, it is possible that SJM's overall earnings outlook is shaping up slightly worse than previously anticipated. The guidance range ( \(8.50 - 9.50\) ) remains unusually wide, and the stepped- up Brazil tariffs are both incremental to SJM's prior outlook and likely to flow through SJM's COGS a month or two before offsetting pricing actions take hold. A quarter ago, we think investors interpreted the upper half of SJM's range as being more likely, with the bottom \(0.50\) providing a cushion in case more challenges arose. Now we think the set up is probably more down the middle.

We are not confident that the SJM shares are poised for as big of an intra- quarter rally as last quarter. The SJM shares declined \(16\%\) following 4Q25 earnings, when guidance same in below expectations, but then rallied \(16\%\) over the subsequent 2 months (SSPACK \(- 4\%\) ) as coffee elasticity in measured channels tracked well ahead of SJM's guidance. We continue to see upside in the shares over the coming year (hence, our Overweight rating); however, we are less confident that as meaningful of a rally is likely during fiscal 2Q as occurred during 1Q. In fairness, the shares are not down as much, so perhaps not as big of a rally is needed. But we also think investors might be more reticent to count on earnings upside coming from coffee after (a) 1Q missed despite low elasticity and (b) the assumed elasticity is now lower than the prior outlook. And underlying consumption trends for other areas of SJM's business remain less favorable right now and might not infect in 2Q, considering (a) the SKU cuts at Hostess and (b) continue
